Class MediaProcessor

Media processor class holding and running the media processing logic. The class implements an async event emitter pattern

example
  let mediaProcessor: MediaProcessor = new MediaProcessor();
  let transformers: Array<Transformer> = [];
  transformers.push(new CanvasTransform());
  mediaProcessor.setTransformers(transformers);
  mediaProcessor.on('error',(ErrorData => {}))
  mediaProcessor.on('warn',(WarnData => {}))

Hierarchy

  • Emittery<EventDataMap>
    • MediaProcessor

Properties

debug

debug: DebugOptions<EventDataMap>

Inherited from Emittery.debug

Debugging options for the current instance.

Static isDebugEnabled

isDebugEnabled: boolean

Inherited from Emittery.isDebugEnabled

Toggle debug mode for all instances.

Default: true if the DEBUG environment variable is set to emittery or *, otherwise false.

example
import Emittery = require('emittery');

Emittery.isDebugEnabled = true;

const emitter1 = new Emittery({debug: {name: 'myEmitter1'}});
const emitter2 = new Emittery({debug: {name: 'myEmitter2'}});

emitter1.on('test', data => {
// â€¦
});

emitter2.on('otherTest', data => {
// â€¦
});

emitter1.emit('test');
//=> [16:43:20.417][emittery:subscribe][myEmitter1] Event Name: test
//    data: undefined

emitter2.emit('otherTest');
//=> [16:43:20.417][emittery:subscribe][myEmitter2] Event Name: otherTest
//    data: undefined

Static Readonly listenerAdded

listenerAdded: typeof listenerAdded

Inherited from Emittery.listenerAdded

Fires when an event listener was added.

An object with listener and eventName (if on or off was used) is provided as event data.

example
import Emittery = require('emittery');

const emitter = new Emittery();

emitter.on(Emittery.listenerAdded, ({listener, eventName}) => {
console.log(listener);
//=> data => {}

console.log(eventName);
//=> 'ðŸ¦„'
});

emitter.on('ðŸ¦„', data => {
// Handle data
});

Static Readonly listenerRemoved

listenerRemoved: typeof listenerRemoved

Inherited from Emittery.listenerRemoved

Fires when an event listener was removed.

An object with listener and eventName (if on or off was used) is provided as event data.

example
import Emittery = require('emittery');

const emitter = new Emittery();

const off = emitter.on('ðŸ¦„', data => {
// Handle data
});

emitter.on(Emittery.listenerRemoved, ({listener, eventName}) => {
console.log(listener);
//=> data => {}

console.log(eventName);
//=> 'ðŸ¦„'
});

off();

Methods

anyEvent

  • anyEvent(): AsyncIterableIterator<[keyof EventDataMap, WarnData | ErrorData | PipelineInfoData]>

  • Inherited from Emittery.anyEvent

    Get an async iterator which buffers a tuple of an event name and data each time an event is emitted.

    Call return() on the iterator to remove the subscription.

    In the same way as for events, you can subscribe by using the for await statement.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();
    const iterator = emitter.anyEvent();

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ1'); // Buffered
    emitter.emit('ðŸŒŸ', 'ðŸŒˆ2'); // Buffered

    iterator.next()
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done is false
    // value is ['ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ1']
    return iterator.next();
    })
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done is false
    // value is ['ðŸŒŸ', 'ðŸŒˆ2']
    // revoke subscription
    return iterator.return();
    })
    .then(({done}) => {
    // done is true
    });

    Returns AsyncIterableIterator<[keyof EventDataMap, WarnData | ErrorData | PipelineInfoData]>

    const object = {};

    new Emittery().bindMethods(object);

    object.emit('event');

    Parameters

destroy

  • Stops running the tranformation logic performed by the media processor instance.

    Returns Promise<void>

emit

  • emit<Name>(eventName: Name): Promise<void>
  • emit<Name>(eventName: Name, eventData: EventDataMap[Name]): Promise<void>

  • Inherited from Emittery.emit

    Trigger an event asynchronously, optionally with some data. Listeners are called in the order they were added, but executed concurrently.

    Type parameters

    • Name: never

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name

    Returns Promise<void>

    A promise that resolves when all the event listeners are done. Done meaning executed if synchronous or resolved when an async/promise-returning function. You usually wouldn't want to wait for this, but you could for example catch possible errors. If any of the listeners throw/reject, the returned promise will be rejected with the error, but the other listeners will not be affected.

  • Inherited from Emittery.emit

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name
    • eventData: EventDataMap[Name]

    Returns Promise<void>

emitSerial

  • emitSerial<Name>(eventName: Name): Promise<void>
  • emitSerial<Name>(eventName: Name, eventData: EventDataMap[Name]): Promise<void>

  • Inherited from Emittery.emitSerial

    Same as emit(), but it waits for each listener to resolve before triggering the next one. This can be useful if your events depend on each other. Although ideally they should not. Prefer emit() whenever possible.

    If any of the listeners throw/reject, the returned promise will be rejected with the error and the remaining listeners will not be called.

    Type parameters

    • Name: never

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name

    Returns Promise<void>

    A promise that resolves when all the event listeners are done.

  • Inherited from Emittery.emitSerial

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name
    • eventData: EventDataMap[Name]

    Returns Promise<void>

events

  • events<Name>(eventName: Name | Name[]): AsyncIterableIterator<EventDataMap[Name]>

  • Inherited from Emittery.events

    Get an async iterator which buffers data each time an event is emitted.

    Call return() on the iterator to remove the subscription.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();
    const iterator = emitter.events('ðŸ¦„');

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ1'); // Buffered
    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ2'); // Buffered

    iterator
    .next()
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done === false
    // value === 'ðŸŒˆ1'
    return iterator.next();
    })
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done === false
    // value === 'ðŸŒˆ2'
    // Revoke subscription
    return iterator.return();
    })
    .then(({done}) => {
    // done === true
    });

    In practice you would usually consume the events using the for await statement. In that case, to revoke the subscription simply break the loop.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();
    const iterator = emitter.events('ðŸ¦„');

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ1'); // Buffered
    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ2'); // Buffered

    // In an async context.
    for await (const data of iterator) {
    if (data === 'ðŸŒˆ2') {
    break; // Revoke the subscription when we see the value `ðŸŒˆ2`.
    }
    }

    It accepts multiple event names.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();
    const iterator = emitter.events(['ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸ¦Š']);

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ1'); // Buffered
    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦Š', 'ðŸŒˆ2'); // Buffered

    iterator
    .next()
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done === false
    // value === 'ðŸŒˆ1'
    return iterator.next();
    })
    .then(({value, done}) => {
    // done === false
    // value === 'ðŸŒˆ2'
    // Revoke subscription
    return iterator.return();
    })
    .then(({done}) => {
    // done === true
    });

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name | Name[]

    Returns AsyncIterableIterator<EventDataMap[Name]>

off

  • off<Name>(eventName: Name | Name[], listener: (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]) => void | Promise<void>): void

  • Inherited from Emittery.off

    Remove one or more event subscriptions.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();

    const listener = data => console.log(data);
    (async () => {
    emitter.on(['ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸ¶', 'ðŸ¦Š'], listener);
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'a');
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¶', 'b');
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¦Š', 'c');
    emitter.off('ðŸ¦„', listener);
    emitter.off(['ðŸ¶', 'ðŸ¦Š'], listener);
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'a'); // nothing happens
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¶', 'b'); // nothing happens
    await emitter.emit('ðŸ¦Š', 'c'); // nothing happens
    })();

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap | keyof _OmnipresentEventData

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name | Name[]
    • listener: (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]) => void | Promise<void>
        • (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]): void | Promise<void>

        • Parameters

          • eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]

          Returns void | Promise<void>

    Returns void

on

  • on<Name>(eventName: Name | Name[], listener: (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]) => void | Promise<void>): UnsubscribeFn

  • Inherited from Emittery.on

    Subscribe to one or more events.

    Using the same listener multiple times for the same event will result in only one method call per emitted event.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();

    emitter.on('ðŸ¦„', data => {
    console.log(data);
    });

    emitter.on(['ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸ¶'], data => {
    console.log(data);
    });

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ'); // log => 'ðŸŒˆ' x2
    emitter.emit('ðŸ¶', 'ðŸ–'); // log => 'ðŸ–'

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap | keyof _OmnipresentEventData

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name | Name[]
    • listener: (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]) => void | Promise<void>
        • (eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]): void | Promise<void>

        • Parameters

          • eventData: EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]

          Returns void | Promise<void>

    Returns UnsubscribeFn

    An unsubscribe method.

onAny

  • onAny(listener: (eventName: keyof EventDataMap, eventData: WarnData | ErrorData | PipelineInfoData) => void | Promise<void>): UnsubscribeFn

  • Inherited from Emittery.onAny

once

  • once<Name>(eventName: Name | Name[]): Promise<EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]>

  • Inherited from Emittery.once

    Subscribe to one or more events only once. It will be unsubscribed after the first event.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    const emitter = new Emittery();

    emitter.once('ðŸ¦„').then(data => {
    console.log(data);
    //=> 'ðŸŒˆ'
    });

    emitter.once(['ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸ¶']).then(data => {
    console.log(data);
    });

    emitter.emit('ðŸ¦„', 'ðŸŒˆ'); // Logs `ðŸŒˆ` twice
    emitter.emit('ðŸ¶', 'ðŸ–'); // Nothing happens

    Type parameters

    • Name: keyof EventDataMap | keyof _OmnipresentEventData

    Parameters

    • eventName: Name | Name[]

    Returns Promise<EventDataMap & _OmnipresentEventData[Name]>

    The event data when eventName is emitted.

setTrackExpectedRate

  • setTrackExpectedRate(trackExpectedRate: number): void

  • Sets the expected rate of the track per second. The media processor will use this number for calculating drops in the rate. This could happen when the transformation will take more time than expected. This will not cause an error, just warning to the client. Mostly: Video: 30 frames per second Audio: 50 audio data per second for OPUS

    Parameters

    • trackExpectedRate: number

      number holds the predicted track rate.

    Returns void

setTransformers

  • setTransformers(transformers: Transformer<any, any>[]): Promise<void>

  • Sets an array of transfromer instances that will be hold and ran by the media processor instance.

    Parameters

    • transformers: Transformer<any, any>[]

      An array of transformer instances.

    Returns Promise<void>

transform

  • transform(readable: ReadableStream<any>, writable: WritableStream<any>): Promise<void>

  • Starts running the tranformation logic performed by the media processor instance.

    Parameters

    • readable: ReadableStream<any>

      Readable stream associated to the media source being processed.

    • writable: WritableStream<any>

      Writable stream associated to the resulting media once processed.

    Returns Promise<void>

Static mixin

  • mixin(emitteryPropertyName: string | symbol, methodNames?: readonly string[]): <T>(klass: T) => T

  • Inherited from Emittery.mixin

    In TypeScript, it returns a decorator which mixins Emittery as property emitteryPropertyName and methodNames, or all Emittery methods if methodNames is not defined, into the target class.

    example
    import Emittery = require('emittery');

    @Emittery.mixin('emittery')
    class MyClass {}

    const instance = new MyClass();

    instance.emit('event');

    Parameters

    • emitteryPropertyName: string | symbol
    • Optional methodNames: readonly string[]

    Returns <T>(klass: T) => T

      • <T>(klass: T): T

      • In TypeScript, it returns a decorator which mixins Emittery as property emitteryPropertyName and methodNames, or all Emittery methods if methodNames is not defined, into the target class.

        example
        import Emittery = require('emittery');

        @Emittery.mixin('emittery')
        class MyClass {}

        const instance = new MyClass();

        instance.emit('event');

        Type parameters

        • T: new () => any

        Parameters

        • klass: T

        Returns T
